title: How to Make Chewy Caramel

steps.headline: Grease the cooking pot lightly with butter.
Turn on a TV show and place in a position that is viewable while stirring.
Place a cold glass of water and vanilla next to the stove top.
Combine the sugar, brown sugar, corn syrup, evaporated milk, whipping cream, and 1 cup of butter in the pot.
Stir constantly over medium high heat with a wooden mixing spoon.
steps.description: Stir until the mixture is smooth and begins to bubble.

steps.headline: Check the sides of the pot for visible sugar granules.
steps.description: If there are granules, use a plastic spatula to scrape them off the side of the pot.

steps.headline: Test whether the caramel mixture is ready.
steps.description: Drip one drop of mixture into a cold cup of water using a wooden spoon.

steps.headline: Remove the mixture from the water if the sugar forms a ball that does not flatten when removed from the water.
steps.description: Proceed to the next step. If the sugar forms a ball that does not flatten when removed from the water, proceed to the next step. If the mixture dissolves in the water, or forms a ball that flattens in your hand, continue to stir and repeat the testing process in 5 minutes.

steps.headline: Remove the pot from the heat.
Carefully pour the caramel mixture into the prepared pan.
Allow the mixture to cool completely while you take a break.
Apply oil to the blade of a knife.
steps.description: When the blade starts to starts to stick to the caramel, reapply oil to the blade each time.

steps.headline: Cut a sheet of caramel into one inch (2.5cm) wide strips.
steps.description: Do this by scoring the surface with the knife, repeatedly on the same line.

steps.headline: Cut each strip of caramel into one inch (2.5cm) squares by applying firm downward force with the knife.
Line a container with parchment or wax paper.
Place the caramel squares in the container so that they are not touching.
steps.description: When there is no more space on a level, cover with another sheet of parchment or wax paper and repeat.

steps.headline: Store in the fridge.
steps.description: These caramels will keep in the fridge indefinitely but they keep better in your stomach!

text: Cooking the caramel mixture Grease the cooking pot lightly with butter.  Turn on a TV show and place in a position that is viewable while stirring.  Place a cold glass of water and vanilla next to the stove top.  Combine the sugar, brown sugar, corn syrup, evaporated milk, whipping cream, and 1 cup of butter in the pot.  Stir constantly over medium high heat with a wooden mixing spoon. Stir until the mixture is smooth and begins to bubble. Check the sides of the pot for visible sugar granules. If there are granules, use a plastic spatula to scrape them off the side of the pot. Stir for ten minutes.  Testing the caramel mixture Test whether the caramel mixture is ready. Drip one drop of mixture into a cold cup of water using a wooden spoon. Remove the mixture from the water if the sugar forms a ball that does not flatten when removed from the water. Proceed to the next step. If the sugar forms a ball that does not flatten when removed from the water, proceed to the next step. If the mixture dissolves in the water, or forms a ball that flattens in your hand, continue to stir and repeat the testing process in 5 minutes. Remove the pot from the heat.  Shaping the caramels Carefully pour the caramel mixture into the prepared pan.  Allow the mixture to cool completely while you take a break.  Apply oil to the blade of a knife. When the blade starts to starts to stick to the caramel, reapply oil to the blade each time. Cut a sheet of caramel into one inch (2.5cm) wide strips. Do this by scoring the surface with the knife, repeatedly on the same line. Cut each strip of caramel into one inch (2.5cm) squares by applying firm downward force with the knife.  Line a container with parchment or wax paper.  Place the caramel squares in the container so that they are not touching. When there is no more space on a level, cover with another sheet of parchment or wax paper and repeat. Store in the fridge. These caramels will keep in the fridge indefinitely but they keep better in your stomach!
